message.content:
<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: String line = "34 55 64";
StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(line);
int x = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
int y = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
int z = Integer.parseInt(st.nextToken());
System.out.println("x: " + x + ", y: " + y + ", z: " + z);
<<<explanation>>>: In order to parse numbers from a string, you can use the StringTokenizer class to split the string into tokens. Each token can then be converted to an integer using the Integer.parseInt() method. In this example, the string "34 55 64" is split into three tokens using the default delimiter (whitespace). The first token is assigned to the variable x, the second token is assigned to the variable y, and the third token is assigned to the variable z. Finally, the values of x, y, and z are printed to the console.
